Planned Changes to Improve Safety (40 CFR 68.115(f))

The facility continues to have efforts to improve our program and safety systems. There is a process in place for the management team to review all potential process changes, including recommendations following process hazard analysis and compliance audits.  Given our safety record, we believe we have excellent processes in place to maintain safe operation to comply with the provisions of the accidental release prevention regulations under 40 CFR Part 68.

accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are addressed in the RMP / PSM Implementation Program document which details the RMP / PSM program requirements as well as how Hilti will comply with the applicable requirements. The site is not a responding facility for releases of the RMP listed chemicals, so the site utilizes an Emergency Action Plan.  

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-specific Prevention Steps (40 CFR 68.115(c))

The Hilti DFW Warehouse is not required to implement the Program Level 3 prevention program requirements under the RMP regulations because they are eligible for RMP Program Level 1.  However, the Hilti DFW Warehouse is required to comply with the requirements for preventing or minimizing the consequences of catastrophic releases of flammable or explosive chemicals codified under the Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations (29 CFR 1910.119).  The required elements of the PSM prevention program are listed below:

-  Employee Participation
-  Process Safety Information
-  Process Hazard Analysis
-  Operating Procedures
-  Contractors
-  Pre-startup Safety Review
-  Mechanical Integrity
-  Hot Work Permit
-  Management of Change
-  Incident Investigation
-  Emergency Planning and Response
-  Compliance Audits

These items, their specific requirements, and how the Hilti DFW Warehouse will comply with the requirements are addressed in the RMP / PSM Implementation Program document.

Five-year Accident History (40 CFR 68.115(d))

The Hilti DFW Warehouse has had zero RMP reportable incidents in the previous five years.  

Emergency Response Program (40 CFR 68.115(e))

In the event of an aerosol-related emergency, Hilti will notify the Dallas Fire Department to respond and will evacuate their employees when needed.  Additional details related to emergency procedures can be located in the facility's emergency action plan that is included in the RMP / PSM Implementation Program do

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled (40 CFR 68.115(b))

Hilti Inc. (Hilti), a construction equipment and chemicals supplier, leases a warehouse located at 3737 Rock Quarry Rd. STE 400, Dallas, TX (DFW Warehouse). The DFW Warehouse serves as a distribution center for various construction tools, fasteners, and chemicals, including insulation foams and sealants in the form of aerosol cans.  The aerosol foam cans are received at the warehouse inbound area in full pallet format, generally up to 16 cans per carton with a maximum of 64 cartons per pallet.  All flammable aerosols are stored together in a chain-link fenced cage within the cold (<80 F) storage area of the facility.  Customer pick orders list the number of individual cans, cartons, or pallets of material that are selected for relocation to the outbound area. These aerosols contain propellants that include flammable substances that are subject to Process Safety Management (PSM) and Risk Management Program (RMP) requirements as a flammable mixture. There is no bulk (drum, tote, tank) storage or chemical processing operations at the site. The regulated chemicals at the DFW Warehouse consist of aerosol propellants and include the following:

-  Isobutane (CAS #75-28-5);
-  Butane (CAS #106-97-8);
-  Dimethylether (CAS #115-10-6); and
-  Propane (CAS #74-98-6)

The Hilti DFW Warehouse is eligible for the RMP Program 1 because the facility has not had a reportable release in the previous five years, the distance to the flammable endpoint for a worst-case release is less than the distance to any public receptor, and emergency response procedures are coordinated between Hilti and the Dallas Fire Department. Under Program Level 1, Hilti is only required to include data for the worst-case release scenario, and therefore, only a worst-case scenario is included with this submittal.
